revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|2017 BQ|6}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | name = {{mp|2017 BQ|6}} | background = #FFC2E0 | image = 2017 BQ6 radar rotation.gif | image_size = 260 | caption = Radar image of {{mp|2017 BQ|6}} | discovery_ref =   | discoverer = [[Space Surveillance Telescope]] | discovered = [[Lincoln Laboratory's ETS|Lincoln Lab's ETS]] | mpc_name = {{mp|2017 BQ|6}} | alt_names = E2017-C83 | pronounced = | named_after = | mp_category = [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[Apollo asteroid|Apollo]]{{·}}[[Potentially hazardous object|PHA]]  | orbit_ref =   | epoch = 4 September 2017 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2458000.5) | uncertainty = 3 | observation_arc = 130 days | aphelion = 2.9802 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 0.9133 AU | semimajor = 1.9468 AU | eccentricity = 0.5309 | period = 2.72 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (992 days) | mean_anomaly = 65.132[[Degree (angle)|°]] | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.3628|sup=ms}} / day | inclination = 9.0020° | asc_node = 133.03° | arg_peri = 43.562° | moid = 0.0132 AU (5.1 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|LD]]) | dimensions = 0.156 km {{small|(calculated)}} | rotation = {{val|2.150}} [[Hour|h]]
3 h | albedo = 0.20 {{small|(assumed)}} | spectral_type = [[S-type asteroid|S]] {{small|(assumed)}} | abs_magnitude = 21.4 }} '''{{mp|2017 BQ|6}}''' is a sub-kilometer [[asteroid]] on an eccentric orbit, classified as a [[near-Earth object]] and [[potentially hazardous asteroid]] of the [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo group]], approximately 150 meters in diameter. It was discovered on 26 January 2017, by the [[Space Surveillance Telescope]] at [[Lincoln Laboratory's ETS]] (Atom Site) and passed within 6.6 lunar distances of Earth on 7 February 2017 at 6:36 UT. == Radar imaging == Its closest approach was observed by NASA's [[Goldstone Solar System Radar]] in California's Mojave Desert, determining it to have a number of angular flat surfaces similar to a [[polyhedral die]]. [[File:PIA21452 - Angular Asteroid Composite.jpg|thumb|left|Goldstone radar images of {{mp|2017 BQ|6}}]] {{clear|left}} == Orbit == {{mp|2017 BQ|6}} orbits the Sun with a [[semi-major axis]] of 1.95 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] at a distance of 0.9–3.0 AU once every 2 years and 9 months (992 days). Its orbit has an [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 0.53 and an [[orbital inclination|inclination]] of 9[[Degree (angle)|°]] with respect to the [[ecliptic]]. It has an Earth [[minimum orbital intersection distance]] of {{convert |0.0132 |AU |km |abbr=on |lk=off |sigfig= 3}}, which corresponds to 5.1 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distances]]. [[File:2017BQ6.png|thumb|320px|left|2017 passage across the sky]] {{clear|left}} == Physical characteristics == Based on an [[absolute magnitude]] of 21.4 and an assumed [[Astronomical albedo|albedo]] for stony [[S-type asteroid]]s of 0.20, {{mp|2017 BQ|6}} measures 156 meters in diameter. The body has a [[rotation period]] of 2.15 hours and a brightness amplitude of 0.38 magnitude ({{small|[[LCDB quality code|U=2]]}}). == References == {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |type = 2017-06-05 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: (2017 BQ6) |url = http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=3767007 |publisher = Jet Propulsion Laboratory |accessdate = 21 November 2017}} {{cite web |title = 2017 BQ6 |work = Minor Planet Center |url = http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=2017+BQ6 |accessdate = 21 November 2017}} {{cite web |title = LCDB Data for 2017 BQ6 |publisher = Asteroid Lightcurve Database (LCDB) |url = http://www.minorplanet.info/PHP/GenerateALCDEFPage_Local.php?AstInfo=0%7C2017+BQ6 |accessdate = 21 November 2017}} }} == External links == * [http://www.universetoday.com/133390/asteroid-2017-bq6-looks-like-brick Meet Asteroid 2017 BQ6 — A Giant, Spinning Brick] 12 Feb, 2017 by Bob King * [http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?release=2017-032&rn=news.xml&rst=6742 Asteroid Resembles Dungeons and Dragons Dice] February 10, 2017 * [http://echo.jpl.nasa.gov/asteroids/45P_HMP/HMP_planning.2017.html Goldstone Radar Observations Planning: comet 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova, 2015 BN509, 2017 BW, 2013 WT67, 2017 BQ6, 2013 FK, and 2017 BY93] * [http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/iau/Dangerous.html List Of The Potentially Hazardous Asteroids (PHAs)] * [https://amostech.com/TechnicalPapers/2013/Special_Topics/WOODS.pdf Asteroid Detection with the Space Surveillance Telescope] * {{JPL small body|id=3767007}} {{use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{2017 in space}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2017 BQ6}} [[Category:Apollo asteroids|#]] [[Category:Unnumbered minor planets]] [[Category:Radar-imaged asteroids|#]] [[Category:Potentially hazardous asteroids|#]] [[Category:Near-Earth objects in 2017|20170207]] [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 2017|20170126]]

page.title: A New Theory of the Earth

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[Image:WilliamWhistonComet.jpg|thumb|250px|A portrait of Whiston with a diagram demonstrating his theories of cometary catastrophism described in ''A New Theory of the Earth'']]
'''''A New Theory of the Earth''''' was a book written by [[William Whiston]], in which he presented a description of the divine [[Genesis creation myth|creation]] of the Earth and a posited [[deluge (mythology)|global flood]]. He also postulated that the earth originated from the atmosphere of a comet and that [[catastrophism|all major changes in earth's history]] could be attributed to the action of comets. It was published in 1696 and was well received by intellectuals of the day such as [[Isaac Newton]] and [[John Locke]].<ref>Ignatius Donnelly [http://web.stanford.edu/~meehan/donnelly/whiston.html "Whiston's Flood"] 1999</ref>
==Summary of the book== The book is organized as follows:
* Introduction, discussing the text of [[Creation according to Genesis]] * Book I: ''Lematta'', discussing the premises and assumptions on which his argument is based; * Book II: ''Hypotheses'', discussing his model for the origin of the Earth; * Book III: ''Phaenomena'', discussing evidence predicted by his model; * Book IV: ''Solutions'', discussing how his model explains the evidence; * Appendix: An abstract of his theory drawn from various sources.
===Intro=== In the introduction, Whiston discusses the Mosaic account of creation. He argues for a literal interpretation of [[Book of Genesis|Genesis]], writing: :"We must never forsake the plain, obvious, easy and natural sense, unless where the nature of the thing itself, parallel places, or evident reason, afford a solid and sufficient reason for so doing."
In so doing, he challenges allegorical and mythological interpretations of Genesis, concluding that: :"The Mosaic Creation is not a nice and philosophical account of the origin of all things; but a historical and true representation of the formation of our single Earth out of a confused [[Chaos (cosmogony)|Chaos]], and of the successive and visible changes thereof each Day, till it became the habitation of mankind." (p.3)
He interprets the Genesis account of creation as being only of the preparation of the Earth for mankind, and not as an account of creation from nothing (''[[ex nihilo]]''). He draws this from the text, as the account speaks of the waters that existed before God's first creative act on the first day, implying that the [[Earth]] predates Genesis chapter one.
He interprets the account of "placing the heavenly bodies in the firmament" as simply being a consequence of the terrestrial [[frame of reference]], for the heavenly bodies do in fact [[Modern geocentrism|revolve about the Earth]] from the perspective of a man standing on the Earth.
He describes his [[Arianism]], or the view that [[Jesus]] is subordinate to [[God]] but first in creation, a view considered heretical within much of [[Christianity]]. He also asserts that it is very reasonable to believe that man may well be simply one of many intelligent beings, and certainly not the highest before God. He wrote that humanity was [[Fall (religion)|fallen]], and currently in a miserable state akin to [[probation]].
He concludes the introduction with his three ''Postulata'': # "The obvious or literal sense of scripture is the true and redal one, where no evidence reason can be given to the contrary. # That which is clearly accountable in a natural way, is not, without reason to be ascribed to a miraculous power. # What ancient tradition asserts of the constitution of nature, or of the origin and primitive states of the world, is to be allowed for true, where ‘tis fully agreeable to scripture, reason, and philosophy."
===Book I: Lemmata=== Whiston begins by arguing for the existence of a human [[Soul (spirit)|soul]]. He argues that the [[Newton's laws of motion|Newtonian laws]] of motion provide that matter may never move spontaneously, but only when acted upon by an outside force. He notes that humans, animals, and plants are able to move spontaneously, and concludes that they must be more than "mere matter," which, especially in the case of humans, he argues to be evidence of an incorporeal soul.
===Books II, III, and IV: Phenomena=== In the next sections of his book, Whiston goes on to describe his theory of the creation of the Earth, and the flood. He asserted that the Earth was originally a comet, which God formed from its initial "chaos and void" into a [[Planetary habitability|habitable planet]]. He also argued that the flood itself was caused when the Earth passed through the tail of a comet, which, it was known by that time, are composed largely of water. His analysis was very detailed, and similar ideas were promoted in the 1960s by other [[creationists]] postulating causes for the [[Flood geology|global flood]], along with similarity to the ideas of [[Immanuel Velikovsky]]. However, many of them are in direct conflict with contemporary scientific understandings; and comets are not mentioned in flood accounts.
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliographic Information== * {{cite book | first = William | last = Whiston | year = 1696 | title = A New Theory of the Earth, From its Original, to the Consummation of All Things, Where the Creation of the World in Six Days, the Universal Deluge, And the General Conflagration, As laid down in the Holy Scriptures, Are Shewn to be perfectly agreeable to Reason and Philosophy | publisher = Benjamin Tooke | location = London}}
==See also== * [[William Whiston]] * [[Flood geology]] * [[Catastrophism]] * [[Immanuel Velikovsky]]
==External links and sources== * [http://www.varchive.org/itb/ecwhist.htm "William Whiston and the Deluge"] by [[Immanuel Velikovsky]] * [http://www.stanford.edu/~meehan/donnelly/whiston.html "Whiston's Flood"] * [http://www.folklore.ee/folklore/vol31/jakapi.pdf "William Whiston, The Universal Deluge, and a Terrible Spectacle" by Roomet Jakapi] (PDF) * [http://www.lucasianchair.org/whiston-bib.html Bibliography for William Whiston] at the LucasianChair.org the homepage of the [[Lucasian Professor of Mathematics|Lucasian Chair of Mathematics]] at [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge University]] *[http://lhldigital.lindahall.org/cdm/ref/collection/earththeory/id/1468 ''A New Theory of the Earth''] - full digital facsimile at Linda Hall Library
{{DEFAULTSORT:New Theory of the Earth, A}} [[Category:1696 books]] [[Category:Catastrophism]] [[Category:Flood geology]]

{{primary|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox film | name = A Sacred Duty:
Applying Jewish Values to Help Heal the World | image = A_Sacred_Duty_film_DVD-cover.jpg | caption = Cover image for the DVD | director = [[Lionel Friedberg]] | producer = [[Lionel Friedberg]]
[[Richard H. Schwartz]], associate producer | writer = [[Lionel Friedberg]] | starring = See list of interviewees in the article, biblical quotes read by [[Theodore Bikel]] | music = Andrew Keresztes | cinematography = [[Lionel Friedberg]] | editing = [[Diana Friedberg]] | studio = Zepra International, Inc. | distributor = [[Jewish Vegetarians of North America]] | released = {{Film date|2007|10}} | runtime = 60 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = distributed free }} '''''A Sacred Duty,''''' subtitled ''Applying Jewish values to help heal the world,'' is a 2007 60-minute documentary from [[Jewish Vegetarians of North America]] (JVNA), written and produced by [[Lionel Friedberg]]. The film focuses on Jewish teachings about caring for the earth, treatment of animals, and the environment, with a focus on [[vegetarianism]]. [http://www.jpost.com/ArtsAndCulture/Entertainment/Article.aspx?id=82344 Jacobs, Megan, "Jews ban beef to save the world? New film insists meat-free diet is a religious imperative for every Jew," ''Jerusalem Post,'' ] Interviews with rabbis, activists, and scholars are interspersed with footage and stills illustrating the points being discussed.[http://www.haaretz.com/news/film-aims-to-show-how-jewish-values-can-help-save-the-world-1.233411 Zilber, Ariel, "Film aims to show how Jewish values can help heal the World," ''Haaretz,'' November 17, 2007] ==Synopsis== The film opens with footage of a [[NASA]] rocket launch, an animation of our [[solar system]], and a quote from Deuteronomy 30:19 about choosing between life and death (illustrated with images of the planet Earth as seen from space, contrasted with an exploding [[atom bomb]]). This is followed by a statement that humanity has not been caring for the Earth properly according to Jewish teachings. Next comes a section about ancient Jewish texts and "sacred words" that provide "specific instructions on how to be custodians of the world in which we live." Throughout the film, quotes from the [[Torah]], illustrated with closeups of Hebrew scrolls, Jews praying, and nature scenes, will be contrasted with the various environmental threats facing humanity today. The scene shifts once again to the Earth from space, as the camera moves in to focus on [[Israel]]. The narrator then uses that country as a microcosm of current global problems related to air and water pollution, over-population, [[climate change]], health concerns, etc. The film moves on to look at problems globally, with scenes shot all over the world. The focus then shifts to the United States where all the relevant issues are discussed in detail. Reference is made to the United Nations [[FAO]] 2006 report, [[Livestock's Long Shadow]], which makes the claim that livestock agriculture produces more [[greenhouse gas]]ses than all the world's vehicles combined. Next comes a brief presentation, illustrated with simple animated charts, on how meat production is an inefficient way to produce food for a hungry world. This moves into footage of animal abuses on [[feedlot]]s and [[factory farm]]s and the pollution produced by these facilities. The film then focuses on the advantages of [[vegetarianism]] for reducing pollution and solving world hunger. With a change of diet toward vegetarianism, the film asserts, many of these environmental and health problems can be solved. After some fast-moving images of people and nature accompanied by music, the film ends with the same statement from Deuteronomy about "life and death," voiced over a sunrise. ==Cast== Narrated by Lionel Friedberg. Biblical quotations are read by [[Theodore Bikel]]. The following people appear in the film: '''Chief Rabbis''' *Rabbi [[Shear Yashuv Cohen]]—Ashkenazic Chief Rabbi of Haifa *[[Rabbi David Rosen]]—Former Chief Rabbi of Ireland; International Director of Interreligious Affairs of the [[American Jewish Committee]] '''Other Rabbis''' *Rabbi Michael Cohen - Co-founder of the [[Green Zionist Alliance]] (GZA) and a teacher at the [[Arava Institute]] in Israel{{cite web|url=http://www.greenzionism.org/about-us/staff-and-board/ |title=Volunteers for Israel's Environment — Green Zionist Alliance: The Grassroots Campaign for a Sustainable Israel |publisher=Greenzionism.org |date=2012-08-06 |accessdate=2012-08-26}} *Rabbi Fred Scherlinder Dobb, Adat Shalom [[Reconstructionist Judaism|Reconstructionist]] Congregation; environmental activist, and co-founder of the Green Zionist Alliance *Rabbi Adam Frank - Congregation Moreshet Yisrael, Jerusalem, the largest Conservative synagogue in Israel *Rabbi [[Yonassan Gershom]] - A Breslov Chassid and author *Rabbi Simchah Roth - Torat Hayyim, Herzilia *Rabbi Warren Stone - Temple Emanuel, greater Washington, D.C.; Chair, [[Central Conference of American Rabbis]]' Environmental Committee '''Israeli Environmentalists''' *Dr. Yeshayahu Bar-Or - Chief Scientist: Israel Environmental Ministry *Raanan Boral - Director: Environmental Protection Division of the [[Society of Protection of Nature in Israel]] (SPNI) *Samuel Chayen - Israeli environmental activist *Yael Cohen Paran, Yair Cohen and Eren Ben Yaminy - Leaders of [[Green Course]], an Israeli university-based environmental group *Eli Groner - Teacher of environmental studies at the [[Arava Institute]] *Dr. [[Alon Tal]] - Leading Israeli environmentalist; founder of the [[Israel Union for Environmental Defense]]; co-founder of the Green Zionist Alliance; author of ''Pollution in a Promised Land.'' *Yael Ukeles - Director: Derech Hateva, Jerusalem '''Activists''' *Dr. [[Joel Fuhrman]], M.D. - a proponent of micro-nutrient diet. *[[Roberta Kalechofsky]] - Founder and director of [[Jews for Animal Rights]] (JAR) and Micah Publications; author, editor and publisher. *Dr. [[Richard H. Schwartz]] - Author of ''Judaism and Vegetarianism'' and president of [[Jewish Vegetarians of North America]] (JVNA); Green Zionist Alliance delegate to the World Zionist Congress *Jonathan Wolf - Founder and first president of Jewish Vegetarians of North America (JVNA) ==Production== The idea for the film was inspired by the writings of Richard H. Schwartz ''(Judaism and Vegetarianism, Judaism and Global Survival, etc.)'' who also served as associate producer.From the DVD cover Schwartz had seen the [[Christian Vegetarian Association]]'s 2006 film, ''Honoring God's Creation'', and felt that a similar film would be effective in the Jewish community. At the time, he envisioned the film to be about 30 minutes long.Schwartz, Richard, "Creating a 'Judaism and Vegetarianism' videotape," ''JVNA Online Newsletter,'' July 14, 2005 Production began in 2005 with a basic proposal and outline in the JVNA's newsletter, along with a statement that Lionel Friedberg was willing to do it for "a very low fee, basically to cover his costs."JVNA Online Newsletter, Schwartz, Richard, "We Are Planning to Move Forward With the JVNA Video/Suggestions Welcome",July 28, 2005 The film was underwritten by JVNA, through private contributions.A list of donors is in the film credits. Preliminary drafts of the script were circulated among members of the JVNA advisory committee and others for input and went through numerous revisions. Meanwhile, Schwartz and Friedberg set about interviewing possible participants and filming nature footage in both Israel and the United States. Some stock footage was also acquired. The showing of slaughterhouse footage was controversial. Some members of a test audience in [[Staten Island]], New York, branded it as [[propaganda]]. "Richard and I were accused of making a propaganda film for the vegetarian movement. We were accused of showing 'horrors that are impossible to watch,'" Friedberg recalls.[http://jewishveg.blogspot.com/2011/08/08152011-jvna-online-newsletter.html Response from Lionel Friedberg, producer of "A Sacred Duty," ''JVNA Online Newsletter,'' August 8, 2011] But he felt the graphic footage was necessary. In contrasting his film with the more sanitized versions produced by the [[kosher meat]] industry, Friedberg stated: "To celebrate Judaism by depicting the assembly-line process by which animals are miraculously and happily turned into food for the [[Shabbat]] table without depicting the brutal cruelty and suffering that goes along with that process makes a mockery of the real meaning of our faith." The film opens with a warning that it contains material that might be disturbing to some viewers. ==Distribution== ''A Sacred Duty'' was released [[direct-to-video]] on [[DVD]], with public showings in both Israel and the United States, during October–November 2007. Over 35,000 copies were distributed free of charge to synagogues, educational institutions, and individuals, with permission to show the film without royalties.[http://jewishveg.com/schwartz/history.html http://jewishveg.com/schwartz/history.html] In addition, permission was granted to the public to duplicate and distribute it free of charge.From the DVD cover: ""This DVD may be shown, reproduced, and distributed freely." The full version was also posted on [[YouTube]].{{YouTube|Y9RxmTGHZgE}} Numerous short excerpts have also been edited and re-posted by various YouTube users. ==See also== * [[Jewish vegetarianism]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.asacredduty.com Homepage of the film] {{Vegetarianism and veganism}} {{Portal bar|Animal rights|Film in the United States|Judaism}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sacred Duty}} [[Category:2007 films]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Direct-to-video documentary films]] [[Category:Documentary films about environmental issues]] [[Category:Documentary films about Jews and Judaism]] [[Category:Documentary films about vegetarianism]] [[Category:Vegetarianism and religion]] [[Category:Documentary films about animal rights]] [[Category:Vegetarianism in the United States]]

{{EngvarB|date=April 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox sailor | name = Stanley John Reed | image = Kaapstad17.JPG | image_size = | caption = Bust of Bertie Reed at the V&A Waterfront | birth_name = | fullname = | nickname = Bertie
Biltong Bertie | nationality = South African | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1943|01|19}} | birth_place = [[Port Elizabeth]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2006|12|18|1943|01|19}} | death_place = [[Gordon's Bay]] | height = | weight = | classes = | club = | collegeteam = | coach = | medaltemplates = | show-medals = yes | updated = }} '''Stanley John Reed''', more commonly known as Bertie Reed was a South African yachtsman. He was the first South African to complete three singlehanded circumnavigations.{{cite web | url=http://sailing.org.za/default/team-sa3.php | title=Remembering Bertie Reed | accessdate=1 April 2014}} ==Life== Reed was born in Port Elizabeth in 1943. He joined the [[South African Navy]] in 1961 and served for 21 years. He started sailing whilst in the Navy.{{cite web | url=http://www.navy.mil.za/archive/0912/091208_bertie_reed/article.htm | title=Bertie Reed – The Legend Lives On | publisher=SA Navy | date=12 August 2009 | accessdate=1 April 2014 | author=Stone, Keith | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020020228/http://www.navy.mil.za/archive/0912/091208_bertie_reed/article.htm | archivedate=20 October 2013 | df=dmy-all }} In the 1982/83 [[Velux 5 Oceans Race|BOC Challenge]] race he placed second in the Knysna built yacht, Voortrekker.{{cite web | url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/sa-skipper-bertie-reed-dies-at-63-1.308070#.Uzq4aVfdEp8 | title=SA skipper Bertie Reed dies at 63 | publisher=IOL | date=19 December 2006| accessdate=1 April 2014| author=Williams, Roger}} At the time Voortrekker was 14 years old and considered obsolete. In the [[Velux_5_Oceans_Race#The_BOC_Challenge_1986–87|1986–87]] race he was placed 7th, sailing ''Stabilo Boss'',{{cite web|url=http://www.solocircumnavigation.com/SoloAroundTheWorldRaces/BOC_And_AA_Races/BOC82_83/bocchallenge_1986_1987_results.htm|title=The BOC Challenge 1986–1987 Results|accessdate=29 November 2018}} a yacht subsequently raced as ''[[Maiden (yacht)|Maiden]]''. He was awarded South Africa's highest civilian award for bravery, the Wolraad Woltemade Decoration for his rescue of sailor John Martin whose yacht sank after hitting a submerged iceberg in the Southern Ocean during the 1990–91 BOC Challenge. In 2006 he was inducted into the Single-Handed Sailors' Hall of Fame.{{cite web | url=http://www.windlasscreative.com/shshof_web/bertie_reed.htm | title=Bertie Reed – Hall of Fame | accessdate=2 April 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131129142947/http://www.windlasscreative.com/shshof_web/bertie_reed.htm | archivedate=29 November 2013 | df=dmy-all }}{{cite web | url=http://www.iol.co.za/sport/us-award-for-solo-sa-sailing-hero-1.558609?ot=inmsa.ArticlePrintPageLayout.ot | title=US award for solo SA sailing hero | publisher=IOL | date=8 June 2006| accessdate=1 April 2014| author=Chisholm, Fiona}}{{cite web | url=http://www.sail-world.com/Europe/index.cfm?SEID=0&Nid=21420&SRCID=0&ntid=0&tickeruid=0&tickerCID=0 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20140401134057/http://www.sail-world.com/Europe/index.cfm?SEID=0&Nid=21420&SRCID=0&ntid=0&tickeruid=0&tickerCID=0 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=1 April 2014 | title=2006 Inductees SingleHanded Sailors Hall of Fame | accessdate=1 April 2014 | author=Santos, Sally Ann }} He received [[Springbok colours]] 5 times for sailing. ==Death== He died at his home in [[Gordon's Bay]] from cancer.{{cite web| url=https://www.thedailysail.com/offshore/06/38338/south-african-solo-round-the-world-sailor-bertie-reed-loses-his-fight-with-cancer| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120114174101/http://www.thedailysail.com/offshore/06/38338/south-african-solo-round-the-world-sailor-bertie-reed-loses-his-fight-with-cancer| dead-url=yes| archive-date=14 January 2012| title=South African solo round the world sailor Bertie Reed loses his fight with cancer| date=22 December 2006| accessdate=1 April 2014| author=Boyd, James}} In 2009 a bronze bust of Bertie Reed, by local Cape Town sculptor Charl Frank, was unveiled at the [[Victoria & Alfred Waterfront]] by Sir [[Robin Knox-Johnson]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Reed, Bertie}} [[Category:South African male sailors (sport)]] [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer]] [[Category:South African Navy personnel]] [[Category:People from Port Elizabeth]] [[Category:Single-handed circumnavigating sailors]] {{SouthAfrica-sport-bio-stub}}

[[File:Garjah sorsamisk bokbuss.jpg|thumbnail|The southern Sami bookmobile in [[Nordland]], Norway, with symbols from [[sami drum]]s as decorations. Bieggolmai (or perhaps an [[Akka (spirit)|Akka]]) is shown left, next to the window.]] '''Bieggolmai''' ("the man of the [[wind]]") was the unpredictable [[deity]] of the summer winds and [[storm]]s in [[Sami shamanism|Sami mythology]]. He is generally portrayed with two [[shovel]]s in his [[hand]]s, which he used to shuffle the winds into and out of his [[cave]].<ref>[http://www.tjatsi.fo/?side=491b24523f05ea96689d93e856f99618 www.tjatsi.fo]</ref>
His winter counterpart is Biegkegaellies.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Sami mythology]] [[Category:Sky and weather deities]] [[Category:Wind deities]]

flowerguild = | musicgroup = | parishadmin = | serversguild = | logo = | logosize = | logolink = | logoalt = }} '''Saint Mary of Blachernae''' (full name in [[Greek language|Greek]]: Θεοτόκος των Βλαχερνών (pr. ''Theotókos ton Vlachernón''); [[Turkish language|Turkish]] name: ''Meryem Ana Kilisesi'') is an [[Eastern Orthodox]] church in [[Istanbul]]. The little edifice, built in 1867, got the same dedication as the shrine erected in this place in the fifth century which, until its destruction in 1434, was one of the most important sanctuaries of [[Greek Orthodox Church|Greek]] [[Orthodox Church|Orthodoxy]].The importance of the Church can be – among others – argued from the fact that along the whole Orthodox world (from [[Crete]] to [[Chersonesus Taurica|Cherson]] in [[Crimea]]) many churches were put under the same dedication. Janin (1953), p. 169. ==Location== The church is located in [[Istanbul]], in the district of [[Fatih]], in the neighbourhood of [[Ayvansaray, Istanbul|Ayvansaray]], along ''Mustafa Paşa Bostanı Sokak''. It lies a few hundred meters inside the [[walls of Constantinople|walled]] city, at a short distance from the shore of the [[Golden Horn]]. The building is protected by a high wall, and preceded by a garden. ==History== [[File:To agiasma ton vlahernon.JPG|200px|thumb|The Hagiasma of Blachernae in a drawing of 1877, from A.G. Paspates' ''Byzantine topographical studies'']] In 450, [[Roman Emperor|Empress]] [[Pulcheria|Aelia Pulcheria]] started to build a church near a fountain of [[Holy water in Eastern Christianity|holy water]] ({{lang-el|script=latn|Ayíasma}}) situated outside the [[Walls of Constantinople#Theodosian Walls|walls of Theodosius II]] at the foot of the sixth hill of [[Constantinople]]. After her death in 453, the shrine was completed by her husband, Emperor [[Marcian]].Janin (1953), p. 169. Emperor [[Leo I (emperor)|Leo I]] erected near the church two other buildings: a [[parekklesion]],The ''parekklesion'' is a [[chapel]] leaning to the side of the church or of the narthex. named ''Ayía Sorós'' ("holy reliquary"), since it hosted the holy mantle and robe of the Virgin brought from [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] in 473, and the ''´Ayion Loúsma'' ("sacred bath") edifice, which enclosed the fountain. The importance assumed by the whole complex encouraged the Emperors to lodge in the surroundings and to build there the nucleus of what would in later centuries become the imperial palace of Blachernae.Müller-Wiener (1977). During the first quarter of the 6th century, Emperors [[Justin I]] and [[Justinian I]] restored and enlarged the church. The name of Blachernae may come from old name of Romanians (Vlach, Blac, etc.) and from a small colony of vlachsGherghel (1920), p.4 Saint Mary hosted a famous [[icon]] of the [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Virgin]], named after the church ''[[Blachernitissa|Vlachernítissa]]''. It was painted on wood and revetted with gold and silver. This icon and the [[relics]] of the Virgin kept in the parekklesion were considered by the Byzantines as most powerful, useful during a war or in case of natural disasters. The first proof of the power of these objects came in 626. During that year Constantinople was [[Siege of Constantinople (626)|besieged]] by the combined armies of the [[Avars (Carpathians)|Avars]] and the [[Sassanid Empire|Persians]], while Emperor [[Heraclius]] was away, fighting the Persians in Mesopotamia. The son of the Emperor, [[Constantine III (Byzantine emperor)|Constantine]], together with Patriarch [[Sergius I of Constantinople|Sergius]] and Patrician Bonus carried in procession along the ramparts the icon of the Blachernitissa. Some time later the fleet of the Avars was destroyed.Janin (1953), p. 170. The [[Khan (title)|Khan]] of the Avars afterwards said that he had been frightened by the vision of a young woman adorned with jewels scouring the walls. After the end of the siege, the Byzantines learned with joy that the building of the church, which at that time lay outside the Walls, was the only one not to have been plundered by the invaders. When the victorious Heraclius came back to Constantinople, bringing back the [[True Cross]] which had been captured by the Persians in Jerusalem, the Patriarch received him at Saint Mary. Sometime later, the Emperor built a [[Walls of Constantinople#Walls of Blachernae|single wall]] to protect the church, thus enclosing in the City the suburb of Blachernae.Müller-Wiener (1977). [[File:Constantinople mediaeval map.jpg|200px|thumb|Map of Constantinople around 1420, after [[Cristoforo Buondelmonti]]. The District of Blachernae can be seen on the center left part of the map, surrounded on two sides by the walls of the City, below the Golden Horn.]] The protection of the Virgin of the Blachernae was also credited with the Byzantine victories during the [[Siege of Constantinople (718)|Arab siege of 717-718]], and in 860, during the [[Rus'-Byzantine War (860)|invasion of the Rus']]. In this occasion, the [[The Protection of the Mother of God#Tradition|Veil of the Virgin]] (''mafórion''), which by that time had joined the other relics in the church, was shortly plunged in the sea to invoke the protection of God on the fleet.Janin (1953), p. 171.Each year on 2 July the great feast of the ''deposition of the Veil'' (its transport from Jerusalem to Constantinople) took place in the church. Janin (1953), p. 178. Some days later the Rus' fleet was destroyed. In 926 too, during the war against [[Simeon I of Bulgaria|Simeon of Bulgaria]], the potency of the relics of the Virgin helped convince the Bulgarian Tsar to negotiate with the Byzantines instead of assaulting the City.Janin (1953), p. 171. On August 15, 944, the church received other two important objects: the letter written by King [[Abgar V of Edessa]] to [[Jesus]] and the [[Image of Edessa|Mandylion]]. Both relics were then moved to the [[Church of the Virgin of the Pharos]].Janin (1953), p. 172. St. Mary, being a centre of the veneration of the Images, played also an important role in the religious fights of the Byzantines. During the [[Iconoclasm|Iconoclastic period]], the final session of the [[Council of Hieria]], where the cult of the images was condemned, took place in the church. As a consequence of that decision, Emperor [[Constantine V]] ordered the [[Mosaic#Byzantine mosaics|mosaics]] of the interior destroyed, and substituted them with others representing natural scenes with trees, birds and animals.Janin (1953), p. 175. On that occasion the Icon of the Blachernitissa was also hidden under a layer of silvery mortar. In 843, with the [[Triumph of Orthodoxy|end of Iconoclasm]], the [[Feast of Orthodoxy]] was celebrated for the first time in the church of Blachernae with an ''Agrypnía'' ("holy [[Vigil]]"), which occurred on the first Sunday of [[Lent]]. The Blachernitissa was discovered again during restoration works executed during the reign of [[Romanos III|Romanos III Argyros]],On that occasion Romanos also covered the capitals of the columns with gold and silver foil. Janin (1953), p. 169. and became again one of the most venerated icons of Constantinople. The Church of Saint Mary was completely destroyed during a fire in 1070, and was rebuilt by [[Romanos IV| Romanos IV Diogenes]] and [[Michael VII|Michael VII Doukas]] respecting the old plan. According to [[Anna Komnene]], the so-called "habitual miracle" ({{lang-el|to synetís thavma}}) occurred in the church before the Icon of the Virgin Blachernitissa.Janin (1953), p. 174. On Friday after sunset, when the church was empty, the veil which covered the icon moved up slowly, revealing the face of the Virgin, while 24 hours later it fell again slowly. Anyway, the miracle did not occur regularly, and ceased completely after the [[Fourth Crusade|Latin conquest]] of the City. After the [[Fourth Crusade|Latin invasion of 1204]], the church was occupied by the Latin clergy and placed directly under the [[Holy See]]. Already before the end of the [[Latin Empire]], [[John III Doukas Vatatzes]] redeemed the church and many monasteries for the Orthodox clergy in exchange for money.Janin (1953), p. 172. On February 29, 1434, some noble children who were hunting pigeons on the roof of the church accidentally started a fire, which destroyed the whole complex and the surrounding quarter. The area was largely neglected during the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman period]]. In 1867, the Guild of the Orthodox [[furrier]]s bought the parcel around the holy fountain, and built there a small church. == Description == The religious complex of Blachernae comprised three edifices: The Church of Saint Mary, the Chapel of the reliquary (''Ayía Sorós''), and the Sacred Bath (''´Ayion Loúsma''). The church proper, defined by all the sources as "large" (''mégas naós''), was of [[basilica]] type, with the space divided into three aisles by two [[colonnade]]s. This plan is similar to that of other churches of the early type in Constantinople like [[Monastery of Stoudios|St. John of Stoudios]]. It had a rectangular plan with sides of 96 m and 36 m.Janin (1953), p. 175. Justinian apparently built a dome on the church, since Procopius, in his work ''De Edificiis'', mentions that both colonnades bent in the middle of the [[nave]] describing a semicircle. Emperor [[Justin II]] added the two side arms, giving to the plan the appearance of a cross.Two [[epigrams]] of the ''[[Anthologia Palatina]]'' remember this fact. Janin (1953), p. 175. The reconstruction of 1070 possibly respected this plan. The Spanish ambassador [[Ruy Gonzáles de Clavijo]], who visited Constantinople in 1402, writes that the building was divided into three aisles, with the central higher than the flanking ones. The columns were made of [[Jasper|green Jasper]], while the capitals and the bases of the columns were gilded and carved in white marble.Janin (1953), p. 175. The church by that time had no dome anymore, but a multicoloured compartmented ceiling, decorated with golden garlands. [[File:vlahernskaya.jpg|thumb|The alleged ''Vlachernítissa'' [[Icon]] of the [[Theotokos]], kept in [[Dormition Cathedral, Moscow|Dormition Cathedral]] in the [[Moscow Kremlin]].]] The walls at that time were covered with coloured marble panels, while originally a silvery [[Mortar (masonry)|mortar]] was used. Near the middle of the nave, there was a silver [[Ambon (liturgy)|ambon]], while at the end lied a rich [[iconostasis]] surrounded by sculptures. On the upper part of the walls, there were mosaics representing the miracles of Christ and several episodes of his life up to his [[Ascension of Jesus|Ascension]]. To the church belonged also tribunes and an oratory. The shrine communicated through a porticus and a stairway with the imperial Palace of Blachernae, which – lying on the slope of the hill – overlooked it.Janin (1953), p. 176. On the right of the church lied the ''parekklísion'' of the ''Ayía Sorós'', which contained the dress and robe of the Virgin. The veil and a part of [[Cincture of the Theotokos|her belt]] (now at [[Vatopedi monastery]] on [[Mount Athos]]), were later also kept there. The building was round and had a [[narthex]] and tribunes. An icon of the Virgin donated by Emperor Leo I and his wife [[Verina]] was also worshipped there. On its right was kept the casket – adorned with gold and silver – which contained the relics. They were rescued from the Latin occupation, and after the restoration of the Empire were kept in the church, but were all destroyed during the fire of 1434.A pious legend says that the Blachernitissa survived the disaster, and that after 1453 it was brought to a monastery on [[Mount Athos]] and finally to Moscow. The ''bath'' where the Emperor immersed himself comprised three parts: the robing room where he undressed, the ''kólymbos'' (pool for immersion) and the hall of Saint Photinos. It lay to the right of the parekklesion, and communicated with it through a door.Mamboury (1953), p. 308. The pool consisted of a large room surmounted by a dome with the basin in the middle. It was adorned with icons, and the water poured in the basin from the hands of a marble statue of the Virgin. An Image of Saint Photinos decorated the centre of the dome. Each year, on August 15 (the feast of [[Dormition of the Theotokos|Dormition]]), after the adoration of the ''Mafórion'' (holy veil) of the Virgin, the Emperor plunged three times in the sacred pool. The small church which today encloses the Hagiasma has a trapezoidal plan with sloping roof, and is adorned with icons and frescoes. It is oriented in northwest-southeast direction. The holy fountain, which is believed to have healing powers, is always a favourite destination for Orthodox and Muslim pilgrims, who pour in the pool coins and hair pins. The pilgrim can also ritually wash his eyes at a line of faucets.Ronchey (2010), p. 715 Above them a modern [[palindrome]] inscription says: "[[Nipson anomemata me monan opsin|''Nípson anomímata mi mónan ópsin'']]" ([[Greek language|Greek]]: "Wash the sins not only the eyes"). The water falls into an underground gallery, which according to a tradition links the Hagiasma with [[Church of St. Mary of the Spring (Istanbul)|that in Balıklı]]. The church is run by an [[Bishop|episkopos]] and two [[Priest#Catholicism and Eastern Orthodoxy|papades]].Ronchey (2010), p. 714 Each Friday morning the [[Akathist]] [[Hymn]], composed by [[Sergius I of Constantinople|Patriarch Sergius]] during the [[Siege of Constantinople (626)|Siege of 626]], is sung there. Since the nearby area is not urbanized, it would be possible to explore it in order to understand more about the ancient complex. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Sources== {{refbegin}} *{{cite book|last=Mamboury|first=Ernest |authorlink= Ernest Mamboury|title=The Tourists' Istanbul|publisher=Çituri Biraderler Basımevi|location=Istanbul|year=1953}} *{{cite book|last=Janin|first=Raymond|authorlink=Raymond Janin|title=La Géographie ecclésiastique de l'Empire byzantin. 1. Part: Le Siège de Constantinople et le Patriarcat Oecuménique. 3rd Vol. : Les Églises et les Monastères|publisher=Institut Français d'Etudes Byzantines|language=French|location=Paris|year=1953}} *{{cite book|last=Müller-Wiener|first=Wolfgang | authorlink=Wolfgang Müller-Wiener|title=Bildlexikon Zur Topographie Istanbuls: Byzantion, Konstantinupolis, Istanbul Bis Zum Beginn D. 17 Jh|publisher=Wasmuth|location=Tübingen|language=German| year=1977|isbn=978-3-8030-1022-3}} *{{cite book|last1=Ronchey|first1=Silvia|last2=Braccini|first2=Tommaso| title=Il romanzo di Costantinopoli. Guida letteraria alla Roma d'Oriente|publisher=Einaudi|location=Torino| year=2010|language=Italian|isbn=978-88-06-18921-1}} *{{cite book|last=Gherghel|first=Ilie|title=Cateva consideratiuni la cuprinsul notiunii cuvantului "Vlach"|language=Romanian|location=Bucuresti|publisher=Convorbiri literare|year=1920}} {{refend}} == External links == {{commons category|Church of St. Mary of Blachernae (Istanbul)}} *[http://www.byzantium1200.com/blachernae.html Byzantium 1200 – The Complex of Blachernae] {{Churches and Monasteries of Constantinople}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mary of Blachernae (Istanbul), Church of St.}} [[Category:Byzantine sacred architecture]] [[Category:5th-century churches]] [[Category:Churches completed in 1867]] [[Category:19th-century Eastern Orthodox church buildings]] [[Category:Fatih]] [[Category:Holy springs of Turkey]] [[Category:Greek Orthodox churches in Istanbul]] [[Category:Golden Horn]] [[Category:Greeks in Istanbul]]

revision.text:
{{other uses}} {{redirect|Sandstorm}} {{redirect|Black blizzard|the Yoshihiro Tatsumi manga|Black Blizzard (manga)}} {{refimprove|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox weather type |name=Dust storm |image=Sandstorm in Al Asad, Iraq.jpg |caption=A sandstorm approaching [[Al Asad]], [[Iraq]], just before nightfall on April 27, 2005. |sign=[[Dust]] rising in the air. |type=Mild |effect=May cause [[coughing]] and spread [[dust]]. }} [[File:Sandsturm in der Namib (2017).jpg|thumb|260px|Seen from above, a sandstorm might not look as tough as it really is, [[Namib]] Desert (2017) {{Coordinate|NS= 25/20/07/S|EW=016/03/05/E|type=landmark|region=NA-HA|text=25°20′07″S{{pad|1.0em}}017°03′04″E|name=Sandsturm}}]] {{Weather}} A '''dust storm''' is a [[meteorological phenomenon]] common in [[arid]] and [[semi-arid]] regions. Dust storms arise when a [[Outflow boundary|gust front]] or other strong wind blows loose sand and [[dirt]] from a dry surface. Fine particles are transported by [[Saltation (geology)|saltation]] and suspension, a process that moves soil from one place and [[Deposition (sediment)|deposits]] it in another. [[Drylands]] around [[North Africa]] and the [[Arabian peninsula]] are the main terrestrial sources of airborne dust. It has been argued that{{cite book|last1=Eslamian|first1=Saeid|last2=Eslamian|first2=Faezeh|title=Handbook of Drought and Water Scarcity: Management of Drought and Water Scarcity|date=2017|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-1-351-85113-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=46QzDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT942|accessdate=4 December 2017|language=en}}{{unreliable source|date=January 2018}} poor management of the Earth's drylands, such as neglecting the [[fallow]] system, are increasing dust storms size and frequency from desert margins and changing both the local and global climate, and also impacting local economies.{{cite web |url = http://www.unccd.int/Lists/SiteDocumentLibrary/Publications/Global%20Alarm%20eng.pdf |title = Physics, Mechanics and Processes of Dust and Sandstorms |author = Squires, Victor R. |publisher = Adelaide University, Australia |accessdate = 2007-07-29 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150605094122/http://www.unccd.int/Lists/SiteDocumentLibrary/Publications/Global%20Alarm%20eng.pdf |archivedate = 2015-06-05 |df = }} The term ''sandstorm'' is used most often in the context of [[desert]] sandstorms, especially in the [[Sahara Desert]], or places where sand is a more prevalent soil type than dirt or rock, when, in addition to fine particles obscuring visibility, a considerable amount of larger sand particles are blown closer to the surface. The term ''dust storm'' is more likely to be used when finer particles are blown long distances, especially when the dust storm affects [[urban area]]s. ==Causes== As the force of wind passing over loosely held particles increases, particles of sand first start to vibrate, then to [[Saltation (geology)|saltate]] ("leaps"). As they repeatedly strike the ground, they loosen and break off smaller particles of dust which then begin to travel in suspension. At wind speeds above that which causes the smallest to suspend, there will be a population of dust grains moving by a range of mechanisms: suspension, saltation and [[Downhill creep|creep]]. [[File:Global movement of dust from an Asian dust storm animation.gif|thumb|left|290px|Animation showing the global movement of dust from an [[Asian dust]] storm.]] A study from 2008 finds that the initial saltation of sand particles induces a static electric field by friction. Saltating sand acquires a negative charge relative to the ground which in turn loosens more sand particles which then begin saltating. This process has been found to double the number of particles predicted by previous theories.{{cite web |url=http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2008-01/uom-esf010708.php |title=Electric Sand Findings, University of Michigan Jan. 6, 2008 |publisher=Eurekalert.org |date=2008-01-07 |accessdate=2016-12-04 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160520031124/http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2008-01/uom-esf010708.php |archivedate=2016-05-20 |df= }} Particles become loosely held mainly due to a prolonged drought or arid conditions, and high wind speeds. Gust fronts may be produced by the outflow of rain-cooled air from an intense thunderstorm. Or, the wind gusts may be produced by a dry [[cold front]], that is, a cold front that is moving into a dry air mass and is producing no [[Precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]]—the type of dust storm which was common during the [[Dust Bowl]] years in the U.S. Following the passage of a dry cold front, [[convection|convective]] instability resulting from cooler air riding over heated ground can maintain the dust storm initiated at the front. In desert areas, dust and sand storms are most commonly caused by either thunderstorm outflows, or by strong pressure gradients which cause an increase in wind velocity over a wide area. The vertical extent of the dust or sand that is raised is largely determined by the stability of the atmosphere above the ground as well as by the weight of the particulates. In some cases, dust and sand may be confined to a relatively shallow layer by a low-lying [[temperature inversion]]. In other instances, dust (but not sand) may be lifted as high as 20,000 feet (6,100 m) high. [[Drought]] and [[wind]] contribute to the emergence of dust storms, as do poor [[farming]] and grazing practices by exposing the dust and sand to the wind. One poor farming practice which contributes to dust storms is [[dryland farming]]. Particularly poor dryland farming techniques are [[Tillage#Intensive tillage|intensive tillage]] or not having established [[crop]]s or [[cover crop]]s when storms strike at particularly vulnerable times prior to [[revegetation]].{{cite web|title=Dust Storms Chapter |url=http://csc.uoregon.edu/opdr/sites/csc.uoregon.edu.opdr/files/docs/ORNHMP/OR-SNHMP_%2520dust-storms_chapter.pdf |work=Emergency Management Plan |publisher=State of Oregon |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021013222/http://csc.uoregon.edu/opdr/sites/csc.uoregon.edu.opdr/files/docs/ORNHMP/OR-SNHMP_%20dust-storms_chapter.pdf |archivedate=2013-10-21 |df= }} In a semi-arid climate, these practices increase susceptibility to dust storms. However, [[soil conservation]] practices may be implemented to control wind erosion. {{clear}} ==Physical and environmental effects== [[File:A Sand Wind on the Desert.jpg|thumb|250px|Dust storm in Sahara, painted by [[George Francis Lyon]]]] [[File:Sydney_harbour_bridge_duststorm.jpg|thumbnail|250px|[[Sydney]] shrouded in dust during the [[2009 Australian dust storm]].]] A sandstorm can transport and carry large volumes of sand unexpectedly. Dust storms can carry large amounts of dust, with the leading edge being composed of a wall of thick dust as much as {{convert|1.6|km|mi|abbr=on}} high. Dust and sand storms which come off the [[Sahara Desert]] are locally known as a [[simoom]] or simoon (sîmūm, sîmūn). The ''[[haboob]]'' (həbūb) is a sandstorm prevalent in the region of [[Sudan]] around [[Khartoum]], with occurrences being most common in the summer. The [[Sahara]] desert is a key source of dust storms, particularly the [[Bodélé Depression]]{{cite journal|doi=10.1088/1748-9326/1/1/014005|title=The Bodélé depression: A single spot in the Sahara that provides most of the mineral dust to the Amazon forest|journal=Environmental Research Letters|volume=1|pages=014005|year=2006|last1=Koren|first1=Ilan|last2=Kaufman|first2=Yoram J|last3=Washington|first3=Richard|last4=Todd|first4=Martin C|last5=Rudich|first5=Yinon|last6=Martins|first6=J Vanderlei|last7=Rosenfeld|first7=Daniel|bibcode=2006ERL.....1a4005K}} and an area covering the confluence of [[Mauritania]], [[Mali]], and [[Algeria]].{{cite journal|jstor=3650666 |doi=10.1111/1475-5661.00013|title=Saharan dust: Sources and trajectories|journal=Transactions of the Institute of British Geographers|volume=26|issue=2|pages=165|year=2001|last1=Middleton|first1=N. J.|last2=Goudie|first2=A. S.}} Saharan dust storms have increased approximately 10-fold during the half-century since the 1950s, causing topsoil loss in [[Niger]], [[Chad]], northern [[Nigeria]], and [[Burkina Faso]].{{Fact|date=May 2018}} In Mauritania there were just two dust storms a year in the early 1960s, but there are about 80 a year today, according to Andrew Goudie, a professor of geography at Oxford University.Brown, Lester R. (June 27, 2007) [http://www.ipsnews.net/2007/06/environment-around-the-globe-farmers-losing-ground/ ENVIRONMENT: Around the Globe, Farmers Losing Ground] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220163520/http://www.ipsnews.net/2007/06/environment-around-the-globe-farmers-losing-ground/ |date=2016-12-20 }}. ipsnews.net{{cite web |url=http://www.earth-policy.org/Books/Seg/PB2ch05_ss3.htm |title=Losing Soil |accessdate=2007-06-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629132531/http://www.earth-policy.org/Books/Seg/PB2ch05_ss3.htm |archivedate=2007-06-29 |author = Brown, Lester R. }} Levels of Saharan dust coming off the east coast of Africa in June 2007 were five times those observed in June 2006, and were the highest observed since at least 1999, which may have cooled Atlantic waters enough to slightly reduce hurricane activity in late 2007.Loney, Jim (August 9, 2007) [https://www.reuters.com/article/us-weather-hurricanes-dust-idUSN0920911120070809 Scientists examine African dust link to hurricanes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220061042/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-weather-hurricanes-dust-idUSN0920911120070809 |date=2016-12-20 }}. Reuters{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/topics/earth/features/cooling_dust.html |title=NASA: Saharan Dust Has Chilling Effect on North Atlantic |publisher=Nasa.gov |date=December 2007 |accessdate=2016-12-04 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170531104215/https://www.nasa.gov/topics/earth/features/cooling_dust.html |archivedate=2017-05-31 |df= }} Dust storms have also been shown to increase the spread of disease across the globe.{{cite journal|doi=10.1128/CMR.00039-06|pmid=17630335|pmc=1932751|title=Atmospheric Movement of Microorganisms in Clouds of Desert Dust and Implications for Human Health|journal=Clinical Microbiology Reviews|volume=20|issue=3|pages=459–77, table of contents|year=2007|last1=Griffin|first1=D. W.}} Virus spores in the ground are blown into the atmosphere by the storms with the minute particles and interact with urban air pollution.{{cite journal|doi=10.1097/EDE.0b013e31818809e0|pmid= 18854705 |year= 2008 |author1= Sandstrom |first1= T |title= Desert dust: An unrecognized source of dangerous air pollution? |journal= Epidemiology |volume= 19 |issue= 6 |pages= 808–9 |last2= Forsberg |first2= B }} Short-term effects of exposure to desert dust include immediate increased [[symptoms]] and worsening of the [[lung function]] in individuals with [[asthma]],{{cite journal|doi=10.1111/j.1440-1843.2005.00728.x|pmid=16135170|title=Effects of ambient particulate matter on peak expiratory flow rates and respiratory symptoms of asthmatics during Asian dust periods in Korea|journal=Respirology|volume=10|issue=4|pages=470|year=2005|last1=Park|first1=Jeong Woong|last2=Lim|first2=Young Hee|last3=Kyung|first3=Sun Young|last4=An|first4=Chang Hyeok|last5=Lee|first5=Sang Pyo|last6=Jeong|first6=Seong Hwan|last7=Ju|first7=Young-Su}} increased [[mortality rate|mortality]] and [[morbidity]] from long-transported dust from both Saharan{{cite journal|doi=10.1097/EDE.0b013e31818131cf|pmid=18938653|title=Coarse Particles from Saharan Dust and Daily Mortality|journal=Epidemiology|volume=19|issue=6|pages=800|year=2008|last1=Perez|first1=Laura|last2=Tobias|first2=Aurelio|last3=Querol|first3=Xavier|last4=Künzli|first4=Nino|last5=Pey|first5=Jorge|last6=Alastuey|first6=Andrés|last7=Viana|first7=Mar|last8=Valero|first8=Natalia|last9=González-Cabré|first9=Manuel|last10=Sunyer|first10=Jordi}} and [[Asian dust]] storms{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.atmosenv.2013.06.046|title=Effect of Asian dust storms on daily mortality in seven metropolitan cities of Korea|journal=Atmospheric Environment|volume=79|pages=510|year=2013|last1=Lee|first1=Hyewon|last2=Kim|first2=Ho|last3=Honda|first3=Yasushi|last4=Lim|first4=Youn-Hee|last5=Yi|first5=Seungmuk|bibcode=2013AtmEn..79..510L}} suggesting that long-transported dust storm particles adversely affects the circulatory system. [[Dust pneumonia]] is the result of large amounts of dust being inhaled. Prolonged and unprotected exposure of the [[respiratory system]] in a dust storm can also cause [[silicosis]],{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.envint.2013.10.011 |pmid=24275707 |title=Desert dust and human health disorders |journal=Environment International |volume=63 |pages=101–13 |year=2014 |last1=Goudie |first1=Andrew S. }} which, if left untreated, will lead to [[asphyxia]]tion; silicosis is an incurable condition that may also lead to [[lung cancer]]. There is also the danger of [[keratoconjunctivitis sicca]] ("dry eyes") which, in severe cases without immediate and proper treatment, can lead to [[blindness]].{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} ===Economic impact=== Dust storms cause soil loss from the dry lands, and worse, they preferentially remove organic matter and the nutrient-rich lightest particles, thereby reducing agricultural productivity. Also the abrasive effect of the storm damages young crop plants. Dust storms also reduced visibility affecting aircraft and road transportation. In addition dust storms also create problems due to complications of breathing in dust.{{cite web| title =Dust Between Tigris and Euphrates Rivers, Iraq| publisher =Earth Snapshot| date =March 3, 2012| url =http://www.eosnap.com/image-of-the-day/dust-between-tigris-and-euphrates-rivers-iraq-march-3rd-2012/| accessdate =2013-11-20| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20140529051915/http://www.eosnap.com/image-of-the-day/dust-between-tigris-and-euphrates-rivers-iraq-march-3rd-2012/| archivedate =May 29, 2014| df =}} Dust can also have beneficial effects where it deposits: Central and South American rain forests get most of their mineral nutrients from the Sahara; iron-poor ocean regions get iron; and dust in Hawaii increases [[Plantain (cooking)|plantain]] growth. In northern China as well as the mid-western U.S., ancient dust storm deposits known as [[loess]] are highly fertile soils, but they are also a significant source of contemporary dust storms when soil-securing vegetation is disturbed.{{verify source|{{cite web|title=the Dust Bowl|work=Mishe Vanatta|url=http://atlantisonline.smfforfree2.com/index.php?topic=15424.5;wap2|accessdate=2013-11-20|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202235528/http://atlantisonline.smfforfree2.com/index.php?topic=15424.5;wap2|archivedate=2013-12-02|df=}}|date=May 2016}}{{better source|date=May 2016}} ==Extraterrestrial dust storms== {{further|Climate of Mars#Effect of dust storms}} Dust storms are not limited to Earth and have been known to form on other planets such as [[Mars]].{{cite web| title =Discovery Monitoring and Predicting Extraterrestrial Weather| publisher =National Science foundation| url =https://www.nsf.gov/discoveries/disc_summ.jsp?cntn_id=115594| accessdate =2013-11-21| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20141211013731/https://www.nsf.gov/discoveries/disc_summ.jsp?cntn_id=115594| archivedate =2014-12-11| df =}} These dust storms can extend over larger areas than those on Earth, sometimes encircling the planet, with wind speeds as high as {{convert|60|mph|kph}}. However, given Mars' much lower atmospheric pressure (roughly 1% that of Earth's), the intensity of Mars storms could never reach the kind of hurricane-force winds that are experienced on Earth.{{cite web| title =The Fact and Fiction of Martian Dust Storms| publisher =National Aeronautics And Space Administration| url =http://marsmobile.jpl.nasa.gov/news/whatsnew/index.cfm?FuseAction=ShowNews&NewsID=1854| accessdate =2015-09-18| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160914033442/http://marsmobile.jpl.nasa.gov/news/whatsnew/index.cfm?FuseAction=ShowNews&NewsID=1854| archivedate =2016-09-14| df =}} Martian dust storms are formed when solar heating warms the Martian atmosphere and causes the air to move, lifting dust off the ground. The chance for storms is increased when there are great temperature variations like those seen at the equator during the Martian summer.{{cite web| title =THEMIS keeps an eye on Mars for dust| publisher =THEMIS| url =http://themis.asu.edu/dust_activity_monitor| accessdate =2013-11-21| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20130703042347/http://themis.asu.edu/dust_activity_monitor| archivedate =2013-07-03| df =}} [[File:PIA22737-Mars-2018DustStorm-MCS-MRO-Animation-20181030.webm|thumb|center|600px|
[[Atmosphere of Mars|Mars dust storm]] – [[Optical depth|optical depth tau]] – May to September 2018
([[Mars Climate Sounder]]; [[Mars Reconnaisance Orbiter]])
(1:38; animation; 30 October 2018; [[:File:PIA22737-Mars-2018DustStorm-MCS-MRO-Animation-20181030.webm|file description]])
]] {{multiple image |align=center |direction=horizontal |width=300 |image1=PIA22329-Mars-DustStorm-20180606.jpg |image2=PIA16454 Regional Dust Storm Weakening, Nov. 25, 2012.jpg |image3=PIA16450-MarsDustStorm-20121118.jpg |caption1=
[[Opportunity mission timeline#Dust storm|June 6, 2018]]{{cite web |last=Wall |first=Mike |title=NASA's Curiosity Rover Is Tracking a Huge Dust Storm on Mars (Photo) |url=https://www.space.com/40867-nasa-curiosity-rover-mars-dust-storm.html |date=12 June 2018 |work=[[Space.com]] |accessdate=13 June 2018 }}

}} ==See also== {{col-begin}}{{col-break}} * [[Coccidioidomycosis]] * [[Dry line]] * [[Dust Storm Warning]] {{col-break|gap=4em}} * [[Iberulite]]s * [[List of dust storms]] * [[Mineral dust]] {{col-break|gap=4em}} * [[Saharan Air Layer]] * [[Shamal (wind)]] * [[Sirocco]] {{col-end}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons|Dust storm}} * [http://airquality.weather.gov/sectors/conus.php 12-hour U.S. map of surface dust concentrations] Mouse-over an hour block on the row for 'Surface Dust Concentrations' * [http://lubbockonline.com/gallery/dirtygallery/index.htm Slide Show of a Dust Storm] in [[Lubbock, Texas]], on December 15, 2003 * [http://www.islandnet.com/~see/weather/almanac/arc2002/alm02jun.htm ''Dust in the Wind''] * [http://texashistory.unt.edu/search/?q=dust+storms Photos of the April 14 1935 and September 2 1934 dust storms in the [[Texas Panhandle]] hosted by the [http://texashistory.unt.edu/ Portal to Texas History]. * [https://www.lbk.ars.usda.gov/wewc/biblio/bar.htm The Bibliography of Aeolian Research] * [http://www.atmo.arizona.edu/research/dust/dust.html ''University of Arizona Dust Model Page''] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/hi/newsbeat/newsid_7936000/7936912.stm Photos of a sandstorm in Riyadh in 2009] from the BBC Newsbeat website * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xmWuI504WsU&feature=player_embedded#at=82 Dust storm in Phoenix Arizona] via YouTube {{DEFAULTSORT:Dust Storm}} [[Category:Dust storms| ]] [[Category:Weather hazards]] [[Category:Road hazards]]

revision.text:
{{Dynamic list}}
This is a list of the '''fastest animals''' in the world, grouped by types of animal.
==Fastest organism== The fastest land animal is the [[cheetah]], which has a recorded speed of {{convert|109.4|-|120.7|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref name="carwardine08" /> The [[peregrine falcon]] is the fastest bird and the fastest member of the [[animal|animal kingdom]] with a [[Descent (aeronautics)#Dives|diving]] speed of {{convert|242|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}.<ref name="airspacemag.com" /> The fastest animal in the sea is the [[black marlin]], which has a recorded speed of {{convert|80|mph|0|abbr=on|order=flip}}.<ref name=BMarlin/>
While comparing between various classes of animals, a different unit is used, body length per second for organisms. The fastest organism on earth, relative to body length, is the [[mite|South Californian mite]] ''[[Paratarsotomus macropalpis]]'', which has a speed of 322 body lengths per second.<ref name="HT28April2014">{{cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/technology/science/mite-sets-new-record-as-world-s-fastest-land-animal/article1-1213098.aspx |title=Mite runs faster than cheetah, sets record as world's fastest land animal |author=PTI |date=28 April 2014 |work= |publisher=Hindustan Times |accessdate=28 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140428223113/http://www.hindustantimes.com/technology/science/mite-sets-new-record-as-world-s-fastest-land-animal/article1-1213098.aspx |archivedate=28 April 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The equivalent speed for a human running as fast as this mite would be {{convert|1300|mph|km/h|abbr=on|0}}.<ref name="ScienceDaily">{{cite web |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/04/140427191124.htm |title=Mite sets new record as world's fastest land animal |author=Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology (FASEB) |date=27 April 2014 |work=Featured Research |publisher=ScienceDaily |accessdate=28 April 2014}}</ref> This is far in excess of the previous record holder, the [[tiger beetle|Australian tiger beetle]], ''[[Tiger beetle|Cicindela eburneola]]'', the fastest insect in the world relative to body size, which has been recorded at {{convert|1.86|m/s|km/h mph}} or 171 body lengths per second.<ref name="InsectRecords">{{cite web |url=http://entnemdept.ifas.ufl.edu/walker/ufbir/chapters/chapter_39.shtml |title=Chapter 39: Fastest Runner |author=Merritt, Thomas M. |date=31 July 1999 |work=Book of Insect Records |publisher=University of Florida |accessdate=28 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110111245/http://entnemdept.ifas.ufl.edu/walker/ufbir/chapters/chapter_39.shtml |archivedate=10 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The [[cheetah]], the fastest land mammal, scores at only 16 body lengths per second <ref name="HT28April2014" /> while [[Anna's hummingbird]] has the highest known length-specific velocity attained by any vertebrate {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ '''List of animals by speed''' ! Rank ! Animal ! Maximum speed ! Class ! Notes |- |1 |[[Peregrine falcon]] |{{convert|242|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}<ref name="airspacemag.com">[http://www.airspacemag.com/flight-today/falcon.html Falling with the Falcon | Flight Today | Air & Space Magazine<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name=":0">[http://www.extremescience.com/peregrine-falcon-video.htm Video of peregrine falcon<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> |Flight-diving |The peregrine falcon is the fastest aerial animal, fastest animal in flight, fastest bird, and the overall fastest member of the [[animal|animal kingdom]]. The peregrine achieves its highest velocity not in horizontal level flight, but during its characteristic hunting stoop. While stooping, the peregrine falcon soars to a great height, then dives steeply at speeds of over {{convert|200|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref name="airspacemag.com">[http://www.airspacemag.com/flight-today/falcon.html Falling with the Falcon | Flight Today | Air & Space Magazine<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> |- |2 |[[Golden eagle]] |{{convert|150-200|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} |Flight-diving | |- |3 |[[White-throated needletail|White-throated needletail swift]] |{{convert|105|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}<ref name="trails">{{cite web|url=http://www.trails.com/arts/amazing-bird-records.aspx|title=trails.com|publisher=|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="travelalmanac">{{cite web|url=http://www.thetravelalmanac.com/lists/birds-speed.htm|title=travelalmanac.com|publisher=|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="newton">{{cite web|url=http://www.newton.dep.anl.gov/natbltn/200-299/nb215.htm|title=Newton|publisher=|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref> |Flight | |- |4 |[[Eurasian hobby]] |{{convert|100|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}<ref name="bob">{{cite web|last=Seago|first=Michael J|title=Birds of Britain - Hobby, Falco subbuteo|url=http://www.birdsofbritain.co.uk/bird-guide/hobby.asp|accessdate=13 January 2013}}</ref> |Flight |Can sometimes outfly the [[needletail swift|swift]] |- |5 |[[Mexican free-tailed bat]] horizontal speed (as opposed to stoop diving speed) of any animal. |- |6 |[[Frigatebird]] |{{convert|153|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}<ref name="Frigatebird">[http://www.onekind.org/education/top_10_lists/test/ been recorded stripping line off a fishing reel at {{convert|120|ft/s|mph km/h|0}}.<ref name="BMarlin" /> |- |10 |[[Gyrfalcon]] |{{convert|128|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} |Flight | |- |11 |[[Grey-headed albatross]] |{{convert|127|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}<ref name="Guinness World Records Limited">{{cite web | title=Guinness Records - Fastest Bird Level Flight | |last=Catry |first=Paulo |last2=Phillips |first2=Richard |date=13 May 2004 |title=Sustained fast travel by a gray-headed albatross (Thalassarche chrysostoma) riding an antarctic storm |url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.1642/0004-8038%282004%29121%5B1208%3ASFTBAG%5D2.0.CO%3B2?journalCode=tauk |journal=The Auk |doi=10.1642/0004-8038(2004)121[1208:SFTBAG]2.0.CO;2 |accessdate=21 |[[Cheetah]] |{{convert|109.4|-|120.7|km/h|abbr=on}}{{efn|Different sources cite different speeds; estimates include {{convert|96|-|120|km/h|abbr=on}},<ref name=carwardine08 /> ==Birds== {{See also|List of birds by flight speed}}
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Animal ! Maximum recorded speed ! Notes |- | [[Peregrine falcon]] || {{convert|242|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}<ref name="airspacemag.com">[http://www.airspacemag.com/flight-today/falcon.html Falling with the Falcon | Flight Today | Air & Space Magazine<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name=":0">[http://www.extremescience.com/peregrine-falcon-video.htm Video of peregrine falcon<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> || The peregrine falcon is the fastest bird, and the fastest member of the [[animal|animal kingdom]]. When in its hunting dive, the stoop, it soars to a great height, then dives steeply at speeds of over {{convert|200|mph|abbr=on}}. However, it does not hold first place when travelling in level flight. |- | [[Golden eagle]] || {{convert|150-200|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}} || In full stoop, a golden eagle can reach spectacular speeds of up to 240 to 320 kilometers per hour (150 to 200 mph) when diving after prey. Although less agile and maneuverable, the golden eagle is apparently quite the equal and possibly even the superior of the peregrine falcon's stooping and gliding speeds. |- | [[White-throated needletail]] || {{convert|105|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}<ref name= trails>{{cite web|url=http://www.trails.com/arts/amazing-bird-records.aspx|title=trails.com|publisher=|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=travelalmanac>{{cite web|url=http://www.thetravelalmanac.com/lists/birds-speed.htm|title=travelalmanac.com|publisher=|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=newton>{{cite web|url=http://www.newton.dep.anl.gov/natbltn/200-299/nb215.htm|title=Newton|publisher=|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref> || The fastest-flying bird in flapping flight. |- | [[Eurasian hobby]] || {{convert|100|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}<ref name=bob>{{cite web|last=Seago|first=Michael J|title=Birds of Britain - Hobby, Falco subbuteo|url=http://www.birdsofbritain.co.uk/bird-guide/hobby.asp|accessdate=13 January 2013}}</ref> || It can sometimes even outfly birds such as the [[swift]] when hunting. |- |[[Frigatebird]] |{{convert|153|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}<ref name="Frigatebird"/> |The frigatebird's high speed is helped by its having the largest wing-area-to-body-weight ratio of any bird. |- |[[Rock dove]] (pigeon) |{{convert|92.5|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}<ref name=":Pigeon"/> |Pigeons have been clocked flying {{convert|92.5|mph|abbr=on}} average speed on a {{convert|400|mi|adj=on}} race. |- |[[Spur-winged goose]] |{{convert|142|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}<ref name="speedofanimals.com"/> | |- |[[Red-breasted merganser]] |{{convert|129|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}<ref name="ReferenceA">[http://www.speedofanimals.com/animals/red_breasted_merganser]</ref> | |- |[[Gyrfalcon]] |{{convert|128|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} | |- |[[Grey-headed albatross]] |{{convert|127|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}<ref name="Guinness World Records Limited"/><ref name="Catry"/><ref group="note">Sustained ground speed for approximately nine hours with no rest on high tailwinds during an Antarctic storm.</ref> | |- | [[Anna's hummingbird]] || {{convert|61.06|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}<ref name=":3">[http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/276/1670/3047 Courtship dives of Anna's hummingbird offer insights into flight performance limits<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> || The stated speed equals 276 body lengths per second, the highest known length-specific velocity attained by any vertebrate. |- | [[Ostrich]] || {{convert|60|mph|1|abbr=on|order=flip}}<ref name=":5">[http://www.gopetsamerica.com/animals/bird_records.aspx GopetsAmerica Extreme Facts About Birds Records, Fastest running bird: ostrich<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> || The ostrich is the tallest and heaviest species of all living birds. Although its bulky body means that flying is out of the question, the ostrich has adapted to life on the ground with impressive agility. Ostriches are superb runners that can sprint at speeds of up to {{convert|45|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kidszoo.org/our-animals/african-journey/ostrich/|title=Ostrich : Fort Wayne Children's Zoo|publisher=|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref> on average, with a peak {{convert|60|mph|km/h|1|abbr=on}} during short periods, with {{convert|12|ft|m|adj=on}} strides. This also makes the ostrich the fastest animal on two legs. The ostrich is also an endurance runner and can jog at {{convert|30|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} for as long as half an hour. |- |} <references group="note" />
==Reptiles== {| class="wikitable" |- !Animal !Maximum recorded speed ! Notes |- | [[Central bearded dragon]] || {{convert|25.00|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}<ref>{{cite web|publisher=a-z animals|title=Bearded dragons|url=http://a-z-animals.com/animals/bearded-dragon/}}</ref> | |- | [[Green Iguana]] || {{convert|22.00|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}<ref>[http://purelyfacts.com/question/14/is-a-gilamonster-faster-than-an-iguana?DDA=43&DDB=58]</ref> || Green Iguanas are the largest lizards to dwell in trees, and can move faster than the fastest snake can move along the ground. |- | [[Leatherback sea turtle]] || {{convert|21.92|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}<ref name="Guinness1992">{{cite book | last =McFarlan | first =Donald | title =Guinness Book of Records 1992 | publisher=Guinness | year =1991 | location =New York | pages = | isbn = }}</ref> || Leatherback turtles have the most hydrodynamic body design of any sea turtle, with a large, teardrop-shaped body. |- | [[Black mamba]] || {{convert|14.00|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}<ref>[[Black mamba#cite note-Adele2-25]]</ref> || |- | [[Komodo dragon]] || {{convert|13.00|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}<ref name="livescience.com">[http://www.livescience.com/27402-komodo-dragons.html]</ref> ||Komodo dragons are also speedy reptiles. They can run briefly up to 13 mph (21 km/h) but prefer to hunt by stealth.<ref name="livescience.com"/> |}
==Fish== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Animal ! Maximum recorded speed ! Notes |- | [[Black marlin]] || {{convert|80|mph|0|abbr=on|order=flip}}{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} || A hooked black marlin has been recorded stripping line off a fishing reel at {{convert|120|ft/s|mph km/h|0}}. |- | [[Sailfish]] || {{convert|67.85|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} || In a series of tests carried out in a fishing cam at Long Key, Florida, United States, sailfish swam and leapt 91 meters (300 feet) in 3 seconds, equivalent to a speed of {{convert|109|km/h|abbr=on}}, although this speed includes leaps out of the water, which do not strictly qualify as swimming speed. |- | [[Swordfish]] || {{convert|60|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} || The {{convert|60|mph|abbr=on}} figure listed for the swordfish is based on a corrupted version of calculations made by Sir James Gray to estimate the impact speed necessary for a hypothetical {{convert|600|lb|adj=on}} swordfish to embed its sword 3 feet in the timbers of ships, as has been known to occur; the figure seems to have entered the literature without question as though someone had actually timed a swordfish at that speed. |- |[[Yellowfin tuna]] || {{convert|47|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}<ref name=YFtuna>{{cite journal|last=Block|first=Barbara A.|author2=Booth, David |author3=Carey, Francis G. |title=Direct measurement of swimming speeds and depth of blue marlin|journal=Journal of Experimental Biology|year=1992|volume=166|pages=267–284|url=http://jeb.biologists.org/content/166/1/267.full.pdf|accessdate=19 September 2012|publisher=Company of Biologists Ltd.|format=PDF|issn=0022-0949}}</ref> || Many [[tuna]] species are capable of swimming at fast speeds colloquially cited at around {{convert|50|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}. The tails of tuna move fast enough to cause [[cavitation]], which slows them down as vapour accumulates.<ref name=Iosilevskii08>{{cite journal|last1=Iosilevskii|first1=G|last2=Weihs|first2=D|title=Speed limits on swimming of fishes and cetaceans|journal=Journal of The Royal Society Interface|date=6 March 2008|volume=5|issue=20|pages=329–338|doi=10.1098/rsif.2007.1073|url=http://rsif.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/5/20/329.full.pdf|accessdate=26 September 2017|pmc=2607394}}</ref> Tuna have bony fins without nerve endings, which prevents the fish from feeling the pain of cavitation but does not fully protect them from the implosive damage. |- |[[Shortfin mako shark]] || {{convert|45|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} || Underwater and unimpeded by a fishing line, the Shortfin Mako has been reliably clocked at 31 miles (50 kilometres) per hour, and there is a claim that one individual of this species achieved a burst speed of 46 miles (74 kilometres) per hour. But it is extremely difficult to get a fish in the wild to swim in a straight line over a measured course. Laboratory measurements of numerous kinds of fishes — representing a wide range of body sizes — swimming against an artificial current have revealed a surprisingly uniform maximum burst speed of about 10 times the body length per second. Thus, for an average-sized, 6.5-foot (2-metre) Shortfin, its theoretical maximum speed might be something on the order of 45 miles (72 kilometres) per hour. Yet some estimates of the top-speed of a Shortfin Mako are considerably higher. |- |}
